Children could use household items as toys: Children could find ways to make use of everyday household items as toys, such as using cardboard boxes as cars, using plastic bottles as water guns, or using paper clips as building blocks.
Children could create their own toys: Children could use their imagination and creativity to create their own toys from scratch, using materials such as clay, paper, and fabric.
Children could play outside more: Without toys, children would have to rely more on outdoor activities such as playing with balls, frisbees, or kites.
Children could play with each other more: Without toys, children would have to rely more on social activities such as playing games, telling stories, or acting out roles.
Children could learn new skills: Without toys, children would have to rely more on learning new skills such as cooking, gardening, or woodworking.
